CulturalObject.Description: Kissi (or kisi) penny is a term given to a form of indigenous African currency, used in the interior of Sierra Leone in the 19th century. A Kissi penny consists of a rough strip or rod of iron, about a foot in length, which is t-shaped at one end, and flattened at the other.

A gunubri , or lute. It is composed of a rectangular box with wooden sides and decorated with metal studs and shells. Leather is stretched over the sides of the box, and it is played by plucking strings, attached to a cylindrical wooden handle. Though the Glasgow Museum catalogue notes that the lute originated in Sierra Leone, it does not resemble any known Sierra Leonean instruments.
CulturalObject.Materials: Wood; Leather, animal skin; Metal; Bone, ivory, tooth

CulturalObject.Description: A black wooden figure of a girl. The Glasgow Museum catalogue notes that this figure represents a Mende girl prior to initiation into the Sande society. She has elaborate scarification marks on her arms, face, and stomach. This figure remains very glossy, suggesting that it may not have been used. It is carved in a similar style to GLAMG:A.1946.16.b, which may suggest it was made by the same carver.

A black wooden figure of a girl. The Glasgow Museum catalogue notes that this figure represents a Mende girl prior to initiation into the Sande society. She has elaborate scarification marks on her arms and face. This figure remains very glossy, suggesting that it may not have been used. It is carved in a similar style to GLAMG:A.1946.16.a, which may suggest it was made by the same carver.

Kissi (or kisi) penny is a term given to a form of indigenous African currency, used in the interior of Sierra Leone in the 19th century. A Kissi penny consists of a rough strip or rod of iron, about a foot in length, which is t-shaped at one end, and flattened at the other.

Kissi (or kisi) penny is a term given to a form of indigenous African currency, used in the interior of Sierra Leone in the 19th century. A Kissi penny consists of a rough strip or rod of iron, about a foot in length, which is t-shaped at one end, and flattened at the other.

A stone figure, known as nomoli in Mende, carved out of steatite, or soapstone. The age of figures like this one is relatively unknown, however there is evidence to suggest that they Predate Portuguese encounters with the coastal areas of Sierra Leone in the 15th and 16th century. They are thought to have originally represented chiefs or group leaders. More recently, however, such figures have been re-discovered and used as rice gods to encourage high yields. Many believe them to be naturally formed, rather than carved. Other names that have been used for figures such as this one are pompta or mahei yafei . This example depicts a seated male figure, holding a bowl between his hands and feet.

A stone figure, known as nomoli in Mende, carved out of steatite, or soapstone. The age of figures like this one is relatively unknown, however there is evidence to suggest that they Predate Portuguese encounters with the coastal areas of Sierra Leone in the 15th and 16th century. They are thought to have originally represented chiefs or group leaders. More recently, however, such figures have been re-discovered and used as rice gods to encourage high yields. Many believe them to be naturally formed, rather than carved. Other names that have been used for figures such as this one are pompta or mahei yafei . This example is thought to be female and has a cylindrical lump on the back of the head.

This is thought to be a minsereh , or min , figure, though the term has broadly been used to refer to any carved female wooden figures. Min figures are traditionally used as part of the Yasi (Bullom) or Njayei (Mende) society for curing sickness, though they have also been associated with the Sande society. They contain spiritual power which is given to the figure by members of the society rather than the carver. This example has a black patina and a typical ridged hairstyle. She is also wearing waist beads.
CulturalObject.AssociatedPeople: Director of Wellcome Historical Medical Museum in 1949

Min figures are traditionally used as part of the Yasi (Bullom) or Njayei (Mende) society for curing sickness, though they have also been associated with the Sande society. CulturalObject.Description: A carved wooden helmet mask used by the exclusively female Sande (Mende) or Bondo/Bundu (Temne) societies. The mask is traditionally worn by a high-ranking member of the society, the dancing sowei , known as the ndoli jowei among the Mende or a-Nowo among the Temne. Worn with a raffia costume, the masks typically have a polished black finish, with neck rings, elaborate coiffure and dignified facial expression. The mask is thought to represent conceptions of idealised womanhood. This example has no holes for raffia, indicating it is unlikely to have been used. It is similar to a type identified as Gola; there are a number of similar masks in other museum collections, possibly made by the same carver. It has a typical four-ridged hairstyle, with two horns at the front, and two at the back.
CulturalObject.AssociatedPeople: Director of the Wellcome Historical Medical Museum

CulturalObject.Description: A stone figure, known as nomoli in Mende, carved out of steatite, or soapstone. The age of figures like this one is relatively unknown, however there is evidence to suggest that they Predate Portuguese encounters with the coastal areas of Sierra Leone in the 15th and 16th century. They are thought to have originally represented chiefs or group leaders. More recently, however, such figures have been re-discovered and used as rice gods to encourage high yields. Many believe them to be naturally formed, rather than carved. Other names that have been used for figures such as this one are pompta or mahei yafei . This example is covered in pierced holes.

A carved wooden helmet mask used by the exclusively female Sande (Mende) or Bondo/Bundu (Temne) societies. The mask is traditionally worn by a high-ranking member of the society, the dancing sowei , known as the ndoli jowei among the Mende or a-Nowo among the Temne. Worn with a raffia costume, the masks typically have a polished black finish, with neck rings, elaborate coiffure and dignified facial expression. The mask is thought to represent conceptions of idealised womanhood. This example has no holes for raffia, indicating it is unlikely to have been used. It is similar to a type identified as Gola; there are a number of similar masks in other museum collections, possibly made by the same carver. It has two faces, one to the front and one to the back.

Warri is a board game, variants of which are played all over Africa. The Sierra Leone version consists of a carved wooden board in which two rows of six cups are set alongside one another, with two larger receptacles at either end. It is played by distributing counters anti-clockwise. This one is a particularly fine example, with the standard boat-shaped board being supported by two carved male figures. It is complete with 49 bean counters, and one seed.

A carved wooden helmet mask used by the exclusively female Sande (Mende) or Bondo/Bundu (Temne) societies. The mask is traditionally worn by a high-ranking member of the society, the dancing sowei , known as the ndoli jowei among the Mende or a-Nowo among the Temne. Worn with a raffia costume, the masks typically have a polished black finish, with neck rings, elaborate coiffure and dignified facial expression. The mask is thought to represent conceptions of idealised womanhood. This example has no holes for raffia, and is very glossy, indicating that it may not have been used.

Country cloth is a thick, heavy, cloth, traditionally made from locally grown cotton that is spun into thread, dyed, and woven into strips on a tripod loom. The strips are then sewn together edge to edge to form the finished cloth. Such cloth was, in the past, regarded as a sign or wealth and Prestige. This example can be identified as Kpokpo type as it is embroidered and has inlay of navy blue. It also uses both local and imported cotton and is composed of fourteen bands sewn together.

A Mandingo cotton embroidered cap. It is decorated with five rectangular side panels with a central diamond shape, and three panels on the flat top. Mandingo in this context refers to a style of decorated work traditionally worn by Muslim elites.

Country cloth is a thick, heavy, cloth, traditionally made from locally grown cotton that is spun into thread, dyed, and woven into strips on a tripod loom. The strips are then sewn together edge to edge to form the finished cloth. Such cloth was, in the past, regarded as a sign or wealth and Prestige. This example can be identified as Kpokpo type as it is embroidered and has inlay s of white, on navy blue. It is composed of nine strips sewn together.

A carved wooden helmet mask used by the exclusively female Sande (Mende) or Bondo/Bundu (Temne) societies. The mask is traditionally worn by a high-ranking member of the society, the dancing sowei , known as the ndoli jowei among the Mende or a-Nowo among the Temne. Worn with a raffia costume, the masks typically have a polished black finish, with neck rings, elaborate coiffure and dignified facial expression. The mask is thought to represent conceptions of idealised womanhood. This one has a typical ridged hairstyle, a representation of an amulet under the hair crest, and three parallel scars on each cheek.

A carved wooden helmet mask used by the exclusively female Sande (Mende) or Bondo/Bundu (Temne) societies. The mask is traditionally worn by a high-ranking member of the society, the dancing sowei , known as the ndoli jowei among the Mende or a-Nowo among the Temne. Worn with a raffia costume, the masks typically have a polished black finish, with neck rings, elaborate coiffure and dignified facial expression. This example wears a charm case, or amulet, encased in silver. It is thought to be an early example from the early 20th century.

A carved wooden helmet mask used by the exclusively female Sande (Mende) or Bondo/Bundu (Temne) societies. The mask is traditionally worn by a high-ranking member of the society, the dancing sowei , known as the ndoli jowei among the Mende or a-Nowo among the Temne. Worn with a raffia costume, the masks typically have a polished black finish, with neck rings, elaborate coiffure and dignified facial expression. The mask is thought to represent conceptions of idealised womanhood. This example has a central dome-shaped hairstyle, topped with a small rectangle, likely to be an amulet.

A carved wooden helmet mask used by the exclusively female Sande (Mende) or Bondo/Bundu (Temne) societies. The mask is traditionally worn by a high-ranking member of the society, the dancing sowei , known as the ndoli jowei among the Mende or a-Nowo among the Temne. Worn with a raffia costume, the masks typically have a polished black finish, with neck rings, elaborate coiffure and dignified facial expression. The mask is thought to represent conceptions of idealised womanhood. This example has a five ridged hairstyle, and white metal strips nailed along each ridge. It is unusually simple and made from a heavier hardwood, rather than the lighter and more typical cotton tree wood.

A carved wooden helmet mask used by the exclusively female Sande (Mende) or Bondo/Bundu (Temne) societies. The mask is traditionally worn by a high-ranking member of the society, the dancing sowei , known as the ndoli jowei among the Mende or a-Nowo among the Temne. Worn with a raffia costume, the masks typically have a polished black finish, with neck rings, elaborate coiffure and dignified facial expression. The mask is thought to represent conceptions of idealised womanhood. This example has a crown-like central dome and three combs round the side. It is thought to come from the Kenema District.

A large gongoli, or kongoli, mask, depicting the face of a human or animal. The mask has a typical protruding forehead, lips and vertical ears and is complete with its raffia attached. The gongoli masquerader comes out to provide light entertainment, particularly during more solemn occasions such as funerals. It is not particular to any cultural group in Sierra Leone.

A large gongoli, or kongoli, mask, depicting the face of a human or animal. The mask has a typical protruding forehead, lips and vertical ears. This example has been dyed black and has a brass bell attached to the left ear. The gongoli masquerader comes out to provide light entertainment, particularly during more solemn occasions such as funerals. It is not particular to any cultural group in Sierra Leone.

A large gongoli, or kongoli, mask, depicting the face of a human or animal. This example has a protruding jaw and has been painted black, apart from the lips which are orange. The gongoli masquerader comes out to provide light entertainment, particularly during more solemn occasions such as funerals. It is not particular to any cultural group in Sierra Leone.

A large gongoli, or kongoli, mask depicting the face of a human or animal. This example is unusual as is has a large mouth, baring a sharp set of top and bottom teeth, and curved eye flanges on either side of the nose. There is a pointed stump on the chin. The gongoli masquerader comes out to provide light entertainment, particularly during more solemn occasions such as funerals. It is not particular to any cultural group in Sierra Leone.
CulturalObject.Dimensions: overall: 660 mm x 335 mm x 250 mm 2458.5 g

CulturalObject.Description: A large gongoli, or kongoli, mask, depicting the face of a human or animal. This mask has a typical protruding forehead and set of lips, as well as large cusp ears and puffed oval cheeks. It has a waxy grey finish. The gongoli masquerader comes out to provide light entertainment, particularly during more solemn occasions such as funerals. It is not particular to any cultural group in Sierra Leone.

This mask is probably a gongoli, or kongoli, mask, though it is not typical. It has cusp ears carved flat against the face and a small bell attached to the left ear. It has protruding lips which unusually point downwards. The gongoli masquerader comes out to provide light entertainment, particularly during more solemn occasions such as funerals. It is not particular to any cultural group in Sierra Leone.

A large gongoli, or kongoli, mask, depicting the face of a human or animal. This mask has a typical protruding forehead and lips as well as large cusp ears and puffed oval, lopsided, cheeks. The gongoli masquerader comes out to provide light entertainment, particularly during more solemn occasions such as funerals. It is not particular to any cultural group in Sierra Leone.

A large gongoli, or kongoli, mask, depicting the face of a human or animal. This example is blackened, and has large eye flanges and a particularly lop-sided mouth with protruding front teeth. The gongoli masquerader comes out to provide light entertainment, particularly during more solemn occasions such as funerals. It is not particular to any cultural group in Sierra Leone.

This mask is described as a gongoli, or kongoli, mask in the Glasgow Museums catalogue. It is unusual for a gongoli mask, though has the characteristic pointed ears. The gongoli masquerader comes out to provide light entertainment, particularly during more solemn occasions such as funerals. It is not particular to any cultural group in Sierra Leone.

A large gongoli, or kongoli, mask, depicting the face of a human or animal. This example has a brass bell attached to the masks right eye, and a human tooth attached in to the carved mouth. The gongoli masquerader comes out to provide light entertainment, particularly during more solemn occasions such as funerals. It is not particular to any cultural group in Sierra Leone.

A carved wooden A-Rong a-Thoma [ araung etoma or Athoma have also been used] mask from the raGbenle society. It has long downward pointing horns and large rounded triangular nostrils. The mouth is at the base of the mask, with large rectangular teeth. It is worn flat on the head, along with a raffia fringe that is attached to the mask, but missing in this case. The costume also includes a cape and raffia leggings.

A Kabemba, or Ka-bemba, mask worn during the initiation of Temne boys into the Poro society. Ka-bemba means grandfather, or forefather, and is worn by the person who leads the boys into the society bush for circumcision, and then out again. This example is ovoid in shape, with a long triangular nose, three scars on each cheek, and five vertical scar lines on the forehead. It has raffia attached to it through holes drilled round the sides.

A gonde, or gondei, Mask, painted with white and orange. The gonde is an entertainment masker that appears together with the dignified ndoli jowei , or dancing Sowei, of the Sande society. It offers a parody of the latter by its own dishevelled appearance and undignified behaviour. The mask is often an old Sowei mask that is too decayed or damaged to be used for its original purpose. Unlike the ndoli jowei, little attempt is made to conceal the person wearing the mask.

A gonde, or gondei, Mask, painted with white and orange. The gonde is an entertainment masker that appears together with the dignified ndoli jowei, or dancing Sowei, of the Sande society. It offers a parody of the latter by its own dishevelled appearance and undignified behaviour. The mask is often an old Sowei mask that is too decayed or damaged to be used for its original purpose. Unlike the ndoli jowei, little attempt is made to conceal the person wearing the mask.

This resembles a wooden helmet mask used by the exclusively female Sande (Mende) or Bondo/Bundu (Temne) societies. The mask is traditionally worn by a high-ranking member of the society, the dancing sowei , known as the ndoli jowei among the Mende or a-Nowo among the Temne. Worn with a raffia costume, the masks typically have a polished black finish, with neck rings, elaborate coiffure and dignified facial expression. The Glasgow Museums catalogue, however, suggests is may be Humoi mask, or humoi ndoli , meaning dancing humoi . The mask has four diagonally grooved plaits and scarification on its cheeks. The Humoi was a masquerader representing high ranking men in Mende society.

This is thought to be a minsereh , or min , figure, though the term has broadly been used to refer to any carved female wooden figures. Min figures are traditionally used as part of the Yasi (Bullom) or Njayei (Mende) society for curing sickness, though they have also been associated with the Sande society. They contain spiritual power which is given to the figure by members of the society rather than the carver. This example wears nine strings of waist beads and a necklace, and has scarification on her forehead, cheeks, and stomach.

This is thought to be a minsereh , or min , figure, though the term has broadly been used to refer to any carved female wooden figures. Min figures are traditionally used as part of the Yasi (Bullom) or Njayei (Mende) society for curing sickness, though they have also been associated with the Sande society. They contain spiritual power which is given to the figure by members of the society rather than the carver. This example wears four strings of waist beads.

This was documented as a haniwai figure by Guy Masie-Taylor. Haniwai roughly translates as a term from something uncanny ; used with a wooden figure, the term suggests the figure is representative of a forest spirit. Later research by William Hart has, however, suggested that figures like this one are not haniwai but carvings of a snake-charmers female attendant.

This is thought to be a minsereh , or min , figure, though the term has broadly been used to refer to any carved female wooden figures. Min figures are traditionally used as part of the Yasi (Bullom) or Njayei (Mende) society for curing sickness, though they have also been associated with the Sande society. They contain spiritual power which is given to the figure by members of the society rather than the carver. This example has traces of red pigment and a carved necklace, apron, and set of bangles. She is wearing a beaded necklace.
CulturalObject.AssociatedPlaces: Jawe chiefdom by the Kenema-Kailahun road (Collected)

CulturalObject.Description: This is thought to be a minsereh , or min , figure, though the term has broadly been used to refer to any carved female wooden figures. Min figures are traditionally used as part of the Yasi (Bullom) or Njayei (Mende) society for curing sickness, though they have also been associated with the Sande society. They contain spiritual power which is given to the figure by members of the society rather than the carver. This example has a typical segmented neck, and wears a small apron.
CulturalObject.Dimensions: overall: 590 mm x 110 mm x 95 mm 937.5 g

CulturalObject.Description: This is thought to be a minsereh , or min , figure, though the term has broadly been used to refer to any carved female wooden figures. Min figures are traditionally used as part of the Yasi (Bullom) or Njayei (Mende) society for curing sickness, though they have also been associated with the Sande society. They contain spiritual power which is given to the figure by members of the society rather than the carver. This example is, however, unusual as the figure is carrying a baby on her back, and the style of carving is angular. Massie-Taylor noted that it might have been used by the Kuranko Pangbai, or Gbangbe, society.

This is thought to be a minsereh , or min , figure, though the term has broadly been used to refer to any carved female wooden figures. Min figures are traditionally used as part of the Yasi (Bullom) or Njayei (Mende) society for curing sickness, though they have also been associated with the Sande society. They contain spiritual power which is given to the figure by members of the society rather than the carver. This example has a string of glass beads around her neck and has scarification on her face, breasts and stomach. She has a hole pierced through the end of her arm, indicating that she may have originally been holding something.

A carved wooden helmet mask used by the exclusively female Sande (Mende) or Bondo/Bundu (Temne) societies. The mask is traditionally worn by a high-ranking member of the society, the dancing sowei , known as the ndoli jowei among the Mende or a-Nowo among the Temne. Worn with a raffia costume, the masks typically have a polished black finish, with neck rings, elaborate coiffure and dignified facial expression. The mask is thought to represent conceptions of idealised womanhood. This mask comes from the Sierra Leone-Liberia border and has a typical ridged hairstyle. The hairstyle is adorned with rectangular packages and horns, likely to depict charms, or amulets. Such packages commonly held Q uranic texts.

This is thought to be a minsereh , or min , figure, though the term has broadly been used to refer to any carved female wooden figures. Min figures are traditionally used as part of the Yasi (Bullom) or Njayei (Mende) society for curing sickness, though they have also been associated with the Sande society. They contain spiritual power which is given to the figure by members of the society rather than the carver. This example wears a number of necklaces and waist beads, with shell, tooth, seed, and glass, beads.
CulturalObject.Materials: Wood; Bone, ivory, tooth; Glass; Vegetable, organic fibre

CulturalObject.Description: This has been labelled as a minsereh , or min figure, in the Glasgow Museum catalogue, though the term has broadly been used to refer to any carved full-length female wooden figures. This one is particularly unusual as is has no arms, body or feet. Guy Massie-Taylor noted that figures of this type were associated with the Kuranko Pangbai, or Gbangbe, society.

This is thought to be a minsereh , or min , figure, though the term has broadly been used to refer to any carved full-length female wooden figures. Min figures are traditionally used as part of the Yasi (Bullom) or Njayei (Mende) society for curing sickness, though they have also been associated with the Sande society. They contain spiritual power which is given to the figure by members of the society rather than the carver. This example has a triple-domed hairstyle and her ears pierced. She is wearing jewellery, including a necklace, and a bangle on each wrist.

This is thought to be a minsereh , or min , figure, though the term has broadly been used to refer to any carved female wooden figures. Min figures are traditionally used as part of the Yasi (Bullom) or Njayei (Mende) society for curing sickness, though they have also been associated with the Sande society. They contain spiritual power which is given to the figure by members of the society rather than the carver. This example wears a necklace, and a set of waist beads, made of amber and black seed beads. The necklace also has a large tooth string onto it as a pendant.

This is thought to be a minsereh , or min , figure, though the term has broadly been used to refer to any carved female wooden figures. Min figures are traditionally used as part of the Yasi (Bullom) or Njayei (Mende) society for curing sickness, though they have also been associated with the Sande society. They contain spiritual power which is given to the figure by members of the society rather than the carver. This example wears a necklace of red glass beads and has a segmented neck.

This is thought to be a minsereh , or min , figure, though the term has broadly been used to refer to any carved full-length female wooden figures. Min figures are traditionally used as part of the Yasi (Bullom) or Njayei (Mende) society for curing sickness, though they have also been associated with the Sande society. They contain spiritual power which is given to the figure by members of the society rather than the carver. This example is carved from brown wood and has a segmented neck adorned with what look like two vertical horns. She has a typical-ridged hairstyle, with two decorative side disks on wither side.

This is thought to be a minsereh , or min , figure, though the term has broadly been used to refer to any carved full-length female wooden figures. Min figures are traditionally used as part of the Yasi (Bullom) or Njayei (Mende) society for curing sickness, though they have also been associated with the Sande society. They contain spiritual power which is given to the figure by members of the society rather than the carver. This example is Janus-faced; it has two faces, one pointing forward, and the other backwards.

This is thought to be a minsereh , or min , figure, though the term has broadly been used to refer to any carved female wooden figures. Min figures are traditionally used as part of the Yasi (Bullom) or Njayei (Mende) society for curing sickness, though they have also been associated with the Sande society. They contain spiritual power which is given to the figure by members of the society rather than the carver. This example wears three necklaces: one string of red glass beads, and two strings of tiny vertebrae.

An unusual carved female bust, described as a Kissi figure in the Glasgow Museum s catalogue. The figure holds her arms up, bent at the elbow, in one hand she is holding a comb. She has a segmented neck and decorative panels carved above her breasts. Guy Massie Taylor has noted that it was collected on the Kenema-Wando road, which does not confer with the idea that the figure is Kissi. The fact that she is holding a comb might suggest she is representative of a Mende tingoi: a female spirit known to hold a comb in one hand.

An unusual carved female bust wearing shoulder cloths of stained cream, and red, cotton, along with a printed head-tie. She has a ribbed hair design under the scarf, and wears brass earrings. She is also wearing a cowrie shell necklace, with a glass imitation leopards tooth. Although the Glasgow Museum catalogue notes that this is a Mende figure, it rather resembles a Kissi, or Kisi, reliquary for a pompta or nomoli.

A charm/amulet, or sebe/sebbeh: the Mende and Temne name for charm/amulet. It consists of a flat piece of cane, bound with mud and black fabric, and tied with string. Two cowrie shells are attached to it.
A charm/amulet, or sebe/sebbeh: the Mende and Temne name for charm/amulet. It consists of mud, hair, and organic fibre.

A charm/amulet, or sebe/sebbeh: the Mende and Temne name for charm/amulet. It is made from the casing of a Bakelite torch, filled with mud and sealed with mud and string. Two cowrie shells are attached to it.
CulturalObject.Materials: Plastic; Vegetable, organic fibre; Textile; Shell

CulturalObject.Description: A charm/amulet, or sebe/sebbeh: the Mende and Temne name for charm/amulet. It consists of a rectangular pouch of red cotton containing a piece of horn, covered with fabric and tied with string. Four cowrie shells are attached to it.

A small red tunic, probably worn by a carved wooden bust, similar to one in the Glasgow Museums collection, numbered A.1985.13.bk. A.1985.13.bk is thought to be a Kissi, or Kisi, shrine for concealing a nomoli or pompta .
An iron spear head with a missing shaft. The blade type is known as a Lanceolate blade.
An iron spear head with a missing shaft. The blade type is known as a Lanceolate blade.
An iron spear head with a missing shaft. The blade type is known as a Lanceolate blade. This example is very rusted.

A barbed spear head. It consists of an iron tapering blade with small barbs running along its length. The barbs change direction half way up the blade. There are traces of earth, fibre, and white pigment, between the barbs. The shaft is missing.

A small stone figure, known as nomoli in Mende, carved out of steatite, or soapstone. The age of figures like this one is relatively unknown, however there is evidence to suggest that they Predate Portuguese encounters with the coastal areas of Sierra Leone in the 15th and 16th century. They are thought to have originally represented chiefs or group leaders. More recently, however, such figures have been re-discovered and used as rice gods to encourage high yields. Many believe them to be naturally formed, rather than carved. Other names that have been used for figures such as this one are pompta or mahei yafei . This example has a squat head. and sunken eyes with crows feet scarification.

A stone figure, known as nomoli in Mende, carved out of steatite, or soapstone. The age of figures like this one is relatively unknown, however there is evidence to suggest that they Predate Portuguese encounters with the coastal areas of Sierra Leone in the 15th and 16th century. They are thought to have originally represented chiefs or group leaders. More recently, however, such figures have been re-discovered and used as rice gods to encourage high yields. Many believe them to be naturally formed, rather than carved. Other names that have been used for figures such as this one are pompta or mahei yafei .

A small stone figure, known as nomoli in Mende, carved out of steatite, or soapstone. The age of figures like this one is relatively unknown, however there is evidence to suggest that they Predate Portuguese encounters with the coastal areas of Sierra Leone in the 15th and 16th century. They are thought to have originally represented chiefs or group leaders. More recently, however, such figures have been re-discovered and used as rice gods to encourage high yields. Many believe them to be naturally formed, rather than carved. Other names that have been used for figures such as this one are pompta or mahei yafei . This example has bared pointed teeth and a bored hole to one side of its pot-belly; such holes are often found on the stomach or head of nomoli s of this style.

The age of figures like this one is relatively unknown, however there is evidence to suggest that they Predate Portuguese encounters with the coastal areas of Sierra Leone in the 15th and 16th century. They are thought to have originally represented chiefs or group leaders. More recently, however, such figures have been re-discovered and used as rice gods to encourage high yields. Many believe them to be naturally formed, rather than carved. Other names that have been used for figures such as this one are pompta or mahei yafei .

A small stone figure, known as nomoli in Mende, carved out of steatite, or soapstone. The age of figures like this one is relatively unknown, however there is evidence to suggest that they Predate Portuguese encounters with the coastal areas of Sierra Leone in the 15th and 16th century. They are thought to have originally represented chiefs or group leaders. More recently, however, such figures have been re-discovered and used as rice gods to encourage high yields. Many believe them to be naturally formed, rather than carved. Other names that have been used for figures such as this one are pompta or mahei yafei . This example, unusually, has its arms are wrapped round its head, which is resting on its knees and has a hole drilled into the top.

A stone figure, known as nomoli in Mende, carved out of steatite, or soapstone. The age of figures like this one is relatively unknown, however there is evidence to suggest that they Predate Portuguese encounters with the coastal areas of Sierra Leone in the 15th and 16th century. They are thought to have originally represented chiefs or group leaders. More recently, however, such figures have been re-discovered and used as rice gods to encourage high yields. Many believe them to be naturally formed, rather than carved. Other names that have been used for figures such as this one are pompta or mahei yafei .

A carved wooden helmet mask used by the exclusively female Sande (Mende) or Bondo/Bundu (Temne) societies. The mask is traditionally worn by a high-ranking member of the society, the dancing sowei , known as the ndoli jowei among the Mende or a-Nowo among the Temne. Worn with a raffia costume, the masks typically have a polished black finish, with neck rings, elaborate coiffure and dignified facial expression. The mask is thought to represent conceptions of idealised womanhood. The example appears to have a string of teeth surrounding her five lobed hairstyle.

The head of a stone figure, known as nomoli in Mende, carved out of steatite, or soapstone. The age of figures like this one is relatively unknown, however there is evidence to suggest that they Predate Portuguese encounters with the coastal areas of Sierra Leone in the 15th and 16th century. They are thought to have originally represented chiefs or group leaders. More recently, however, such figures have been re-discovered and used as rice gods to encourage high yields. Many believe them to be naturally formed, rather than carved. Other names that have been used for figures such as this one are pompta or mahei yafei . This example has bared pointed teeth and large ears, pointing backwards.

A stone figure, known as nomoli in Mende, carved out of steatite, or soapstone. The age of figures like this one is relatively unknown, however there is evidence to suggest that they Predate Portuguese encounters with the coastal areas of Sierra Leone in the 15th and 16th century. They are thought to have originally represented chiefs or group leaders. More recently, however, such figures have been re-discovered and used as rice gods to encourage high yields. Many believe them to be naturally formed, rather than carved. Other names that have been used for figures such as this one are pompta or mahei yafei .

A stone figure, known as nomoli in Mende, carved out of steatite, or soapstone. The age of figures like this one is relatively unknown, however there is evidence to suggest that they Predate Portuguese encounters with the coastal areas of Sierra Leone in the 15th and 16th century. They are thought to have originally represented chiefs or group leaders. More recently, however, such figures have been re-discovered and used as rice gods to encourage high yields. Many believe them to be naturally formed, rather than carved. Other names that have been used for figures such as this one are pompta or mahei yafei . This example has bulbous eyes, a broad nose, and an open toothed mouth.

A small stone figure, known as nomoli in Mende, carved out of steatite, or soapstone. The age of figures like this one is relatively unknown, however there is evidence to suggest that they Predate Portuguese encounters with the coastal areas of Sierra Leone in the 15th and 16th century. They are thought to have originally represented chiefs or group leaders. More recently, however, such figures have been re-discovered and used as rice gods to encourage high yields. Many believe them to be naturally formed, rather than carved. Other names that have been used for figures such as this one are pompta or mahei yafei . This example is male.

A stone figure, known as nomoli in Mende, carved out of steatite, or soapstone. The age of figures like this one is relatively unknown, however there is evidence to suggest that they Predate Portuguese encounters with the coastal areas of Sierra Leone in the 15th and 16th century. They are thought to have originally represented chiefs or group leaders. More recently, however, such figures have been re-discovered and used as rice gods to encourage high yields. Many believe them to be naturally formed, rather than carved. Other names that have been used for figures such as this one are pompta or mahei yafei . This one has fairly indistinguishable features.

A stone figure, known as nomoli in Mende, carved out of steatite, or soapstone. The age of figures like this one is relatively unknown, however there is evidence to suggest that they Predate Portuguese encounters with the coastal areas of Sierra Leone in the 15th and 16th century. Many believe them to be naturally formed, rather than carved. Other names that have been used for figures such as this one are pompta or mahei yafei . This one has unclear features.

An incomplete stone figure, known as nomoli in Mende, carved out of steatite, or soapstone. The age of figures like this one is relatively unknown, however there is evidence to suggest that they Predate Portuguese encounters with the coastal areas of Sierra Leone in the 15th and 16th century. They are thought to have originally represented chiefs or group leaders. More recently, however, such figures have been re-discovered and used as rice gods to encourage high yields. Many believe them to be naturally formed, rather than carved. Other names that have been used for figures such as this one are pompta or mahei yafei . This one has unclear features.

An incomplete stone figure, known as nomoli in Mende, carved out of steatite, or soapstone. The age of figures like this one is relatively unknown, however there is evidence to suggest that they Predate Portuguese encounters with the coastal areas of Sierra Leone in the 15th and 16th century. They are thought to have originally represented chiefs or group leaders. More recently, however, such figures have been re-discovered and used as rice gods to encourage high yields. Many believe them to be naturally formed, rather than carved. Other names that have been used for figures such as this one are pompta or mahei yafei . The body remains undistinguishable on this example.
A steatite, or soapstone, carinated circular disc, with a hole bored through the middle. Stones such as this are proliferate in Sierra Leone, and thought to be digging weights.
A steatite, or soapstone, carinated circular disc, with a hole bored through the middle. Stones such as this are proliferate in Sierra Leone, and thought to be digging weights.

Half of a steatite, or soapstone, carinated circular disc, with a hole bored through the middle. Stones such as this are proliferate in Sierra Leone, and thought to be digging weights. This one is, however, different from other bored stones as it has a pointed cross section, and a wide inside hole.
This is a carved soapstone fragment. One side is rough, and the other has three ridges. It might be a fragment of a Nomoli.

Warri is a board game, variants of which are played all over Africa. The Sierra Leone version consists of a carved wooden board in which two rows of six cups are set alongside one another, with two larger receptacles at either end. It is played by distributing counters anti-clockwise. This one is particularly unusual with its flanks covered in relief carving. One side depicts a bird, a gun and a yoke, and the other has a bird, two snakes, a door, a pot and a figure with a pipe. The cups at either end are supported by two figures. The Glasgow Museum catalogue notes that this example is Limba.

Warri is a board game, variants of which are played all over Africa. The Sierra Leone version consists of a carved wooden board in which two rows of six cups are set alongside one another, with two larger receptacles at either end. It is played by distributing counters anti-clockwise. This example is traditionally boat-shaped with a geometric stand decorated with a zigzag design.

Warri is a board game, variants of which are played all over Africa. The Sierra Leone version consists of a carved wooden board in which two rows of six cups are set alongside one another, with two larger receptacles at either end. It is played by distributing counters anti-clockwise. This example is typically boat shaped, but sits on four carved wooden wheels. There are carved geometric designs between the cups. The Mende term for a Warri board is te goko .

Warri is a board game, variants of which are played all over Africa. The Sierra Leone version consists of a carved wooden board in which two rows of six cups are set alongside one another, with two larger receptacles at either end. It is played by distributing counters anti-clockwise. This example is rectangular in shape, with simple cross-hatched decoration. It comes from the Tonkolilli District.

Warri is a board game, variants of which are played all over Africa. The Sierra Leone version consists of a carved wooden board in which two rows of six cups are set alongside one another, with two larger receptacles at either end. It is played by distributing counters anti-clockwise. This example is classically boat-shaped with traces of white along the sides. The Glasgow Museum catalogue notes that this one is Mende and from Pujehun. The Mende word for the game is te , with te goko meaning the board.

Warri is a board game, variants of which are played all over Africa. The Sierra Leone version consists of a carved wooden board in which two rows of six cups are set alongside one another, with two larger receptacles at either end. It is played by distributing counters anti-clockwise. This example is classically boat-shaped. The Glasgow Museum catalogue notes that this one is Mende and originated in Dia, Kailahun District. The Mende word for the game is te , with te goko meaning the board.

Warri is a board game, variants of which are played all over Africa. The Sierra Leone version consists of a carved wooden board in which two rows of six cups are set alongside one another, with two larger receptacles at either end. It is played by distributing counters anti-clockwise. This one has no stand, and was apparently made with European tools in the railway workshop in Bo.
A soft wood carving of a hen, or fowl, with an intricate feather design. It is flat bottomed, without legs, and thought to be Mende in origin.
A soft wood spoon with burnt designs on the handle, and around the rim of the spoon. The Glasgow Museums catalogue describes it as a rice scoop .
A soft wood spoon with burnt designs on the handle, and around the rim of the spoon. The Glasgow Museums catalogue describes it as a rice scoop .
A wooden hand bailer, used for removing water that has entered a boat. This example is triangular in shape with a cylindrical handle.
A wooden hand bailer, used for removing water that has entered a boat. This example is triangular in shape with a cylindrical handle.

The Glasgow Museum catalogue notes this is a set of two hand bailers that will be split, once carving is completed. The rectangular projection in the centre would form the top of both handles when it was split.
A wooden hand bailer, used for removing water that has entered a boat. This example is triangular in shape with a cylindrical handle.

A carved wooden helmet mask used by the exclusively female Sande (Mende) or Bondo/Bundu (Temne) societies. The mask is traditionally worn by a high-ranking member of the society, the dancing sowei , known as the ndoli jowei among the Mende or a-Nowo among the Temne. Worn with a raffia costume, the masks typically have a polished black finish, with neck rings, elaborate coiffure and dignified facial expression. The mask is thought to represent conceptions of idealised womanhood. This example has four lines of cowrie shells woven into her five ridged hairstyle.
A paddle used for propelling and steering a canoe. It is carved in soft wood, with a narrow pointed end.
A paddle used for propelling and steering a canoe. It is carved in soft wood, with a narrow pointed end.
A paddle used for propelling and steering a canoe. It is carved in soft wood, with a narrow pointed end. The paddle is decorated with an incised zigzag on one side.

A softwood model of a Sherbro canoe, complete with paddle [GLAMG:A.1985.13.dd.2]. The canoe is pointed and raised at both stern and prow, with creeper bands as struts. The paddle has a geometric design painted in black, red, and blue.

A softwood model of a Sherbro canoe [GLAMG:A.1985.13.dd.1], complete with paddle. The canoe is pointed and raised at both stern and prow, with creeper bands as struts. The paddle has a geometric design painted in black, red, and blue.
A soft wood spoon, or paddle, with a burnt design of circles and lines on the spatula-shaped head. It was probably used for stirring rice.
A soft wood spoon, or paddle, with a spatula shape at both ends, and a burnt design of circles at one end. It was probably used for stirring rice.
A soft wood spoon, or paddle, with a spatula shape at both ends, and a burnt rosette design at one end. It was probably used for stirring rice.
A soft wood rice paddle used for stirring rice. It has a burnt design at one end.
A container made out of a calabash, or gourd. It has a wooden funnel-like mouth piece, attached by twine. The container was probably used for holding palm wine, or poyo .

A container made out of a calabash, or gourd. It has a wooden funnel-like mouth piece, attached by twine, it also has a figurative design etched onto the surface of the gourd. The container was probably used for holding palm wine, or poyo .

A Kuranko woven grass hammock. It has a plaited open weave lozenge pattern with a thick rope for tying it up. It is slung between two pierced hardwood batons which are likely to have been a later addition, possible carved by Guy Massie-Taylor (the collector).

Kissi (or kisi) penny is a term given to a form of indigenous African currency, used in the interior of Sierra Leone in the 19th century. A Kissi penny consists of a rough strip or rod of iron, about a foot in length, which is t-shaped at one end, and flattened at the other.

Kissi (or kisi) penny is a term given to a form of indigenous African currency, used in the interior of Sierra Leone in the 19th century. A Kissi penny consists of a rough strip or rod of iron, about a foot in length, which is t-shaped at one end, and flattened at the other.

Kissi (or kisi) penny is a term given to a form of indigenous African currency, used in the interior of Sierra Leone in the 19th century. A Kissi penny consists of a rough strip or rod of iron, about a foot in length, which is t-shaped at one end, and flattened at the other.

Kissi (or kisi) penny is a term given to a form of indigenous African currency, used in the interior of Sierra Leone in the 19th century. A Kissi penny consists of a rough strip or rod of iron, about a foot in length, which is t-shaped at one end, and flattened at the other.

A wooden staff, thought to have been carried by a high ranking woman in the Kenema Sande society. The staff is carved out of hardwood and depicts a female head at the top, followed by a segmented neck and a snake running down the shaft.

A wooden staff, thought to have been carried by a man of high ranking, possibly a chief, in Pujehun. The staff is carved out of brown hardwood, with a male figure carved into the shaft, wearing a metal ring on one ankle.

A wooden staff, probably carried by a man of high rank. The top of the staff is adorned with a small boat, or receptacle, followed by a rattle carved within the shaft, containing a ball. The Glasgow Museum catalogue notes the staff comes from mountain areas and is Kuranko, or Koranko, with Toma influence.
A carved wooden comb with a female head at the tip, followed by a rattle carved into the handle, consisting of a rectangular box containing a small wooden ball. The comb has four teeth.
A carved wooden comb with a ring held between two leaves at the comb tip. The comb has four teeth, emerging below a panel decorated on one side with a flower and leaves carved in relief.
An undecorated carved wooden comb with four teeth.
An undecorated carved wooden comb with five teeth. The handle is spade shaped.
A carved wooden comb with a triangular tipped handle and six teeth.

A carved wooden comb with an elaborate handle. The handle consists of two pipe bowls attached to a rattle, carved into the shaft of the handle with a small ball in it. The handle and teeth base are decorated with circles carved in relief. The comb has five teeth.
A carved wooden comb with an oval ring at the tip of the handle and floral motifs at the teeth base. It has six teeth.
A carved wooden comb with a long handle, pierced at the teeth base. It has five teeth.

A carved wooden helmet mask used by the exclusively female Sande (Mende) or Bondo/Bundu (Temne) societies. The mask is traditionally worn by a high-ranking member of the society, the dancing sowei , known as the ndoli jowei among the Mende or a-Nowo among the Temne. Worn with a raffia costume, the masks typically have a polished black finish, with neck rings, elaborate coiffure and dignified facial expression. The mask is thought to represent conceptions of idealised womanhood. This example has a strip of tin plate nailed on the centre of the forehead, and five lozenge shaped tin plate ornament nailed around the top.
A wooden hair comb with a triangular handle and five teeth.
An undecorated carved wooden comb with five teeth. The handle is spade shaped and has five teeth.

A sansa (Sasa in Mende), or finger piano. This musical instrument consists of a wooden block, containing a rattle, and sealed with gum. It has 11 metal keys held in place with a metal strip and cane. The instrument is played by plucking the keys; the vibrations are sent down to the piece of cane, which verberates the sound through the box, amplifying it. The keys of a sansa are often made from flattened umbrella spokes.
A brass comb with a semi-circular tip and pierced centre. It has five teeth. Examples of brass casting are rare in Sierra Leone, making this a particularly unusual example.

A kontho , or slit gong. It is carved from a single piece of wood that has been hollowed out through vertical slits in the middle section. The instrument has a stylised head at one end. Kontho is the Limba name for this instrument though the Kuranko also have one that is similar. The Kontho resembles the Mende Kele, or Kili, or the Limba N kali, which also consists of a hollowed log.

A bowl-shaped drum, commonly know as a bote . It has a wooden circular base, with hide stretched over the top, held in place by hide thongs. The bote is decorated with a string of cowrie shells strung around the top, and five cloth flaps with a patchwork geometric patterns. Bote drums are commonly associated with Susu musicians, though are found across Sierra Leone. The Glasgow Museum catalogue notes this one is possibly Mende in origin.
CulturalObject.Materials: Wood; Leather, animal skin; Bone, ivory, tooth; Textile

CulturalObject.Description: This drum resembles a Fula fifaru drum, though the Fula origins of the drum are uncertain as the Glasgow Museum catalogue notes it to be of possible Mende origin. The drum has a long cylindrical wooden body with a tapered end. It is held in place between the thighs when played.

A sangbei drum with a tall hollow body carved out of a light wood. and a wooden plinth at the bottom for balancing it upright on the floor. It has a hide drum head, held in place by a role of orange patterned fabric and thick string.
A carved wooden drum on a plinth, with four rattles attached to it with sticks. The rattles consist of curved metal heads with rings attached through piercings around the edges.

A wooden double ended drum, known as a sangbori . Sangbori drums are most commonly used by Sande women. This example has skin stretched over each end, held in place with blue dyed fabric and string. It resembles the sangbai drum, as it has one drum head that is wider than the other.

A kele or slit drum. It is cylindrical in shape, made out of a hollowed out log. It has three narrow vertical slits of varying lengths along the top and an incised design on one end. It is played standing up, worn with a fibre carrying strap. Other known names for the kele are kili and keleng in Temne.

A bolon , or bolon bata , is commonly known as a Fula instrument; it resembles a harp lute. This example typically consists of a calabash resonator, a curved wooden neck with three strings, and a rattle secured to the end. The calabash is half covered in animal hide, likely to be goat hide, and attached to a red cotton carrying strap. The rattle is made out of a copper sheet, with holes pierced around the edges, securing a number of small rings and bells.
CulturalObject.Materials: Metal; Wood; Leather, animal skin; Textile; cotton

CulturalObject.Description: A Xylophone-like musical instrument, called a balangi , or balanjii , consisting of a series of wooden tone bars or keys attached to a wooden frame with small gourd resonators underneath, played with two beaters. It is particularly associated with the Kuranko, and other ethno-linguistic groups of Mande origin, in northern Sierra Leone. This one has 21 wooden rungs and 17 gourd fruits underneath.

Leg or arm rattles worn by dances and other public performers. They are made from a flat oval piece of iron that is bent over to form a rattle. There is a loop at each end, with two additional loops attached to it that rattle when the wearer moves. These are attached to a leather thong, so that they can be tied to the body.

Leg or arm rattles worn by dances and other public performers. They are made from a flat oval piece of iron that is bent over to form a rattle. There is a loop at each end, with two additional loops attached to it that rattle when the wearer moves. These are attached to a leather thong, so that they can be tied to the body.
CulturalObject.Dimensions: overall: 120 mm x 110 mm x 105 mm 112.5 g

CulturalObject.Description: The segureh or seghura , is a Mende percussion instrument consisting of a small calabash or gourd, surrounded by a string net, strung with small pieces of shell, or nut shell. The gourd is held by the neck in one hand, whilst the other hand pulls the net, causing the shells to clash against the sides of the gourd. It is traditionally used exclusively by women. This example uses black seeds, threaded onto white cotton. Other known names for this instrument are segula , segbula and segbureh .

The segureh or seghura , is a Mende percussion instrument consisting of a small calabash or gourd, surrounded by a string net, strung with small pieces of shell, or nut shell. The gourd is held by the neck in one hand, whilst the other hand pulls the net, causing the shells to clash against the sides of the gourd. It is traditionally used exclusively by women. This example uses black seeds, threaded onto white cotton. Other known names for this instrument are segula , segbula and segbureh .

A disc rattle, know as a lala by the Fula. It consists of 22 gourd discs separated by copper split washers, and held in place by a copper ring. It is played by shaking the wooden handle, and often played in pairs.

A disc rattle, know as a lala by the Fula. It consists of 24 gourd discs separated by copper split washers, and held in place by a copper ring. It is played by shaking the wooden handle, and often played in pairs.
A wooden war horn made of a single piece of flaring wood, with a large mouth hole. Wooden war horn s are known to be used in Liberia, which may relate to the origins of this one.

A nyayaru , or chordophone, known colloquially as a Fula violin. It is composed of a gourd resonator and dark hair stretched over a bridge and up the wooden neck, that ends in a rattle. The gourd resonator is covered in scaled skin, probably snake, and decorated with a burnt design. Is it played with a bow.
CulturalObject.Materials: Vegetable, organic fibre; Wood; Metal; Leather, animal skin

CulturalObject.Description: A recorder with a gourd, or calabash, resonator with three rectangular holes, and one in the base. The instrument consists of a cane stem with six holes and a mouth piece. Attached to the calabash are seven chains with coins attached to the ends, two of which are 5 franc coins, dated to 1956. The Presence of francs suggest it may be a Fula instrument with links to francophone Guinea. This is supported by a photograph taken by Massie-Taylor that shows some Fula musicians playing an instrument of this type.
A bell-shaped blackened iron gong, formed by two triangular pieces of iron, joined at the top by a thick iron stem. It has a leather loop for carrying.
An iron percussion ring, worn on the fingers and used for tapping against a calabash, or gourd. These rings, and the associated calabash, are sometimes known as a horde by Fula musicians.
An iron percussion ring, worn on the fingers and used for tapping against a calabash, or gourd. These rings, and the associated calabash, are sometimes known as a horde by Fula musicians.
An iron percussion ring, worn on the fingers and used for tapping against a calabash, or gourd. These rings, and the associated calabash, are sometimes known as a horde by Fula musicians.
An iron percussion ring, worn on the fingers and used for tapping against a calabash, or gourd. These rings, and the associated calabash, are sometimes known as a horde by Fula musicians.
A large dish made out of a calabash, or gourd. The base is decorated by an elaborate carving; the Glasgow Museum catalogue describes it as a sun . This bowl is thought to have been made in Nigeria.

A large dish made out of a calabash, or gourd. The base of the dish is decorated with an incised pattern of geometric bands and figural motifs, pigmented with black. It is thought to have been made in Freetown.

This is a kokoi , or kpoi and is played in a similar way to a pipe or whistle. It consists of a small gourd with four small holes, and one large one. It is played by blowing across the large hole, and closing and opening the smaller holes with one s fingers. It is played by members of the Poro society.

A carved wooden helmet mask used by the exclusively female Sande (Mende) or Bondo/Bundu (Temne) societies. The mask is traditionally worn by a high-ranking member of the society, the dancing sowei , known as the ndoli jowei among the Mende or a-Nowo among the Temne. Worn with a raffia costume, the masks typically have a polished black finish, with neck rings, elaborate coiffure and dignified facial expression. The mask is thought to represent conceptions of idealised womanhood. This example has two protruding horns coming from the front; in between these is a narrow band of white metal, ending in a disc. The mask has unusual double dot markings across the forehead.

This is a kokoi , or kpoi and is played in a similar way to a pipe or whistle. It consists of a small gourd with four small holes, and one large one. It is played by blowing across the large hole, and closing and opening the smaller holes with one s fingers. It is played by members of the Poro society.

This is a kokoi , or kpoi and is played in a similar way to a pipe or whistle. It consists of a small gourd with four small holes, and one large one. It is played by blowing across the large hole, and closing and opening the smaller holes with one s fingers. It is played by members of the Poro society.

This is a kokoi , or kpoi and is played in a similar way to a pipe or whistle. It consists of a small gourd with four small holes, and one large one. It is played by blowing across the large hole, and closing and opening the smaller holes with one s fingers. It is played by members of the Poro society.
Drum stick, made of light wood.
Drum stick, made of light wood.

A snuff container, made out of Ivory. The end of the horn is carved with two human faces and its body is decorated with circular ring and dot patterns. The snuff container came complete with two metal spoons attached via short chains.
A wooden mortar, commonly used for pounding rice.

A hard wood mortar, probably used for grinding snuff. It has four bowed legs attached to a tubular shaped base which is similar to a rice mortar. The base and the rim appear to have been blackened by burning.
A fan, woven from palm leaf. It is triangular in shape and has a central bract as a handle.
A fan, woven from palm leaf. It is triangular in shape and has a central bract as a handle.

A circular fan. It has been woven out of yellow and natural grass, or raffia, over splints that group in the centre. It has a rectangular handle, bound in yellow and natural raffia, with a plaited loop for hanging.
A Kuranko woven basket for carrying small objects on long journeys. The lid has a raised chequered design, and is attached to the basket with straw twine.
A Kuranko woven basket for carrying small objects on long journeys. The lid has a raised chequered design, and is attached to the basket with straw twine.
This is an adze, or hoe. It was most probably used for breaking up the earth in Preparation for planting.
This is an adze, or hoe. It was most probably used for breaking up the earth in Preparation for planting.
A hooked tool, possibly Mende. It is composed of a rough stick, shaped to a point with an iron hook at tip. Possibly used in the harvesting of pine nuts.
A palm nut dislodger. The long wooden handle and the attached blade were used to dislodge palm nuts that were out of reach.
A knife with an iron blade, and wooden handle.
A machete, most commonly used for clearing vegetation. This example has a handle made from two pieces of hardwood that have been attached to a large curved blade with two nails.
A tube of cane that may be flute mouth piece.
A carved bow shaped piece of wood, with three carved out holes, one filled with fibre. It resembles a pick-axe in shape.
A carved bow shaped piece of wood, with three carved out holes, one filled with fibre. It resembles a pick-axe in shape.
A carved bow shaped piece of wood, with a central hole. It resembles a pick-axe in shape.
A carved bow shaped piece of wood, with a central hole. It resembles a pick-axe in shape.

Two pieces of wood, one partly wrapped in natural fibre. They resemble a group of sticks at the Brighton Museum and Art Gallery that were described by Alldridge as being used for making beads [BMAG:R3483/25a+b+c+d].
A long piece of bone. The Glasgow Museums catalogue notes it may have magical properties.

CulturalObject.ObjectType: Figures, sculpture; Games, toys, models; Tools, implements
CulturalObject.Description: A Mende softwood carving of a small wooden fish. It has a geometric and circular dot design, along with a two pierced holes: one along the side, and the other underneath. The pointed tip, or fish tail, may be an implement of some kind - it resembles the shape of the wooden bird, number GLAMG:A.1985.13.fz, which also has two holes.

CulturalObject.ObjectType: Figures, sculpture; Games, toys, models; Tools, implements
CulturalObject.Description: A Mende softwood carving of a small wooden bird. It has a geometric and circular dot design, along with a two pierced holes: one along the side, and the other underneath. The pointed tip, or bird head, may be an implement of some kind - it resembles the shape of the wooden fish, number GLAMG:A.1985.13.fy, which also has two holes.

A carved wooden helmet mask used by the exclusively female Sande (Mende) or Bondo/Bundu (Temne) societies. The mask is traditionally worn by a high-ranking member of the society, the dancing sowei , known as the ndoli jowei among the Mende or a-Nowo among the Temne. Worn with a raffia costume, the masks typically have a polished black finish, with neck rings, elaborate coiffure and dignified facial expression. The mask is thought to represent conceptions of idealised womanhood. This example has a strip of varnished white metal with a cross motif running along the hair line. The hairstyle is topped by two carved birds.

A Nigerian Ogoni doll, collected from a household where Nigerians had settled for a number of years. Ogoni people historically come from an area in the Niger Delta. It is carved out of softwood and painted white with a black hairstyle and black painted designs on the body.

A Nigerian Ogoni doll, collected from a household where Nigerians had settled for a number of years. Ogoni people historically come from an area in the Niger Delta. It is carved out of softwood and painted white with a black hairstyle and black painted designs on the body.

A Nigerian Ogoni doll, collected from a household where Nigerians had settled for a number of years. Ogoni people historically comes from an area in the Niger Delta. It is carved out of softwood and painted white with a black hairstyle and black painted designs on the body.

A carved wooden figure of a seated woman with pointed breasts and hands resting on her knees. Though the Glasgow Museum catalogue notes that it might be a Mende carving, it is in the style of carving undertaken by the Senufo people of Cote d Ivoire, or Ivory Coast. This may point towards it originally being a commercial carving, never intended for use.

A carved wooden figure of a seated woman with rounded breasts and arms resting on her stomach. Though the Glasgow Museum catalogue notes that it might be a Mende carving, it is in the style of carving undertaken by the Senufo people of Cote d Ivoire, or Ivory Coast. This may point towards it originally being a commercial carving, never intended for use.

A carved wooden figure of a man on horseback. He is carrying a large spear in one had, whilst holding the reins in the other, and is wearing a cap. Though the Glasgow Museum catalogue notes that it might be a Mende carving, the style of carving is more likely to be Nigerian or from the Cote d Ivoire. This may point towards it being for commercial use.
A wooden carved stamp for applying wax to cloth prior to being dyed. Cloth decorated in this way is known is Sierra Leone as garra .
A wooden paddle, used for beating cloth to produce a glaze, or shine.

Country cloth is a thick, heavy, cloth, traditionally made from locally grown cotton that is spun into thread, dyed, and woven into strips on a tripod loom. The strips are then sewn together edge to edge to form the finished cloth. Such cloth was, in the past, regarded as a sign or wealth and Prestige. This example can be identified as Kpokpo type as it is embroidered and has inlay s different colours. It is composed of brown, beige, white, and blue strips, with blue embroidered bands of lozenges at either end. Kondi gula is the Mende word for country cloth.

Country cloth is a thick, heavy, cloth, traditionally made from locally grown cotton that is spun into thread, dyed, and woven into strips on a tripod loom. The strips are then sewn together edge to edge to form the finished cloth. Such cloth was, in the past, regarded as a sign or wealth and Prestige. This example can be identified as Kpokpo type as it is embroidered and has inlay s different colours. It is composed of brown, beige, blue, and ochre strips, with embroidered bands of brocade and diamond motifs at either end. Kondi gula is the Mende word for country cloth.

Country cloth is a thick, heavy, cloth, traditionally made from locally grown cotton that is spun into thread, dyed, and woven into strips on a tripod loom. The strips are then sewn together edge to edge to form the finished cloth. Such cloth was, in the past, regarded as a sign or wealth and Prestige. This example is composed of twelve cotton strips in beige and white, sewn together to create striped pattern.

Country cloth is a thick, heavy, cloth, traditionally made from locally grown cotton that is spun into thread, dyed, and woven into strips on a tripod loom. The strips are then sewn together edge to edge to form the finished cloth. Such cloth was, in the past, regarded as a sign or wealth and Prestige. This example can be identified as Kpokpo type. It is composed of ten indigo strips with horizontal cream stripes, and brocade designs in white.

Country cloth is a thick, heavy, cloth, traditionally made from locally grown cotton that is spun into thread, dyed, and woven into strips on a tripod loom. The strips are then sewn together edge to edge to form the finished cloth. Such cloth was, in the past, regarded as a sign or wealth and Prestige. This example is composed of twelve strips with vertical stripes in beige, cream and faded blue indigo; they have been hemmed by a sewing machine.

Country cloth is a thick, heavy, cloth, traditionally made from locally grown cotton that is spun into thread, dyed, and woven into strips on a tripod loom. The strips are then sewn together edge to edge to form the finished cloth. Such cloth was, in the past, regarded as a sign or wealth and Prestige. This example is composed of twelve strips of blue and white stripes; they have been hemmed by a sewing machine.

Country cloth is a thick, heavy, cloth, traditionally made from locally grown cotton that is spun into thread, dyed, and woven into strips on a tripod loom. The strips are then sewn together edge to edge to form the finished cloth. Such cloth was, in the past, regarded as a sign or wealth and Prestige. This is an example of Kpokpo cloth, probably used for making a hammock. It is composed of nine cotton strips; sewn together they make a chequerboard pattern of cream and indigo, with central panel of embroidered diamonds and interlocking hooks.
A rectangular mat, made from tightly woven cotton in blue, black, and white. It has a central lozenge pattern, with geometric lines at either side. The ends of the mat are fringed.

A rectangular mat, made from tightly woven cotton in yellow, black, and white. It has a central striped panel with raised yellow dashes and an embroidered black lozenge on either side. The ends of the mat are fringed.

A long rectangular mat, made from tightly woven cotton. It is made from two strips that have been sewn together in a similar way to country cloth. The piece is decorated with two small back embroidered lozenges, and the ends are tasselled.
A striped cotton skull cap, probably made out of woven country cloth. It has black, blue, and cream stripes, and is machine stitched. The bottom of the cap is folded up into a rim when worn.

A piece of country cloth, not yet cut and sewn into cloth. Country cloth is a thick, heavy, cloth, traditionally made from locally grown cotton that is spun into thread, dyed, and woven into strips on a tripod loom. The strips are then sewn together edge to edge to form the finished cloth. Such cloth was, in the past, regarded as a sign or wealth and Prestige. This strip has vertical stripes of black, white, brown, and beige; the Glasgow Museum catalogue notes it may be imported.

A natural cotton cloth sample with tucked vertical strips held in place by raffia stitching. This is done in Preparation for dyeing. The dye will not penetrate the tucked lines, leaving a pattern similar to tie-dyeing. The cloth resulting from his dying method is known as garra .

A natural cotton cloth sample, folded and held in place by raffia stitching. This is done in Preparation for dyeing. The dye will not penetrate the tucked lines, leaving a pattern similar to tie-dyeing. The cloth resulting from his dying method is known as garra .

Cotton cloth, divided into four sections and Prepared for dying. Each of the four sections are bound at intervals with raffia; dye will not penetrate through the raffia, leaving a pattern similar to tie-dyeing. The cloth resulting from his dying method is known as garra .

A piece of garra cloth. Garra refers to a method of dying which involves Preparing the cotton by starching, then folding or tucking the cloth, and securing it with raffia or cotton string. When dyed, the dye does not penetrate the parts where it has been folded or tucked, leaving a geometric pattern. This example is composed of 22 strips of cloth, which have been machine stitched together and dyed in indigo blue, and brown.

A piece of garra cloth. Garra refers to a method of dying which involves Preparing the cotton by starching, then folding or tucking the cloth, and securing it with raffia or cotton string. When dyed, the dye does not penetrate the parts where it has been folded or tucked, leaving a geometric pattern. This example consists of 22 strips of imported cotton, machine stitched together, and dyed in indigo and brown.

A piece of garra cloth. Garra refers to a method of dying which involves Preparing the cotton by starching, then folding or tucking the cloth, and securing it with raffia or cotton string. When dyed, the dye does not penetrate the parts where it has been folded or tucked, leaving a geometric pattern. This example consists of two strips of imported cotton, dyed indigo to create vertical panels of a leaf design.

A carved wooden helmet mask used by the exclusively female Sande (Mende) or Bondo/Bundu (Temne) societies. The mask is traditionally worn by a high-ranking member of the society, the dancing sowei , known as the ndoli jowei among the Mende or a-Nowo among the Temne. Worn with a raffia costume, the masks typically have a polished black finish, with neck rings, elaborate coiffure and dignified facial expression. This example has varnished metal strips running along the three ridges of the hairstyle. The style of carving resembles that from the Pujehun district in south-east Sierra Leone, though the Glasgow Museums catalogue states that is comes from the Moyamba district, in the south-west.
CulturalObject.AssociatedPlaces: Mano in Kongbora Chiefdom, Moyamba district; Mano Bonjema, Pujehun (Collected)

CulturalObject.Description: A piece of garra cloth. Garra refers to a method of dying which involves Preparing the cotton by starching, then folding or tucking the cloth, and securing it with raffia or cotton string. When dyed, the dye does not penetrate the parts where it has been folded or tucked, leaving a geometric pattern. This example is composed of three strips if imported cotton, that have been dyed indigo, and folded to create a vertical panels of a palmette design.

A piece of garra cloth. Garra refers to a method of dying which involves Preparing the cotton by starching, then folding or tucking the cloth, and securing it with raffia or cotton string. When dyed, the dye does not penetrate the parts where it has been folded or tucked, leaving a geometric pattern. This example has been dyed indigo.

A piece of garra cloth. Garra refers to a method of dying which involves Preparing the cotton by starching, then folding or tucking the cloth, and securing it with raffia or cotton string. When dyed, the dye does not penetrate the parts where it has been folded or tucked, leaving a geometric pattern. This example has been folded and dyed indigo, to create a pattern of eight zigzags, with sets of small circles in a diamond pattern between each zigzag. Two of the circles have been left untied.

A piece of garra cloth. Garra refers to a method of dying which involves Preparing the cotton by starching, then folding or tucking the cloth, and securing it with raffia or cotton string. When dyed, the dye does not penetrate the parts where it has been folded or tucked, leaving a geometric pattern. This example has been tied and dyed to create a pattern of small circles.

When dyed, the dye does not penetrate the parts where it has been folded or tucked, leaving a geometric pattern. This example has been folded, and dyed indigo, to create vertical lines.

A piece of garra cloth. Garra refers to a method of dying which involves Preparing the cotton by starching, then folding or tucking the cloth, and securing it with raffia or cotton string. When dyed, the dye does not penetrate the parts where it has been folded or tucked, leaving a geometric pattern. This example has been folded and dyed indigo to create five strips of pale blue.

When dyed, the dye does not penetrate the parts where it has been folded or tucked, leaving a geometric pattern. This example has been folded, and dyed with indigo, to create a chequered effect of light and dark blue.

When dyed, the dye does not penetrate the parts where it has been folded or tucked, leaving a geometric pattern. This example has been tied, and dyed with indigo, to create large circles of light blue.

A piece of garra cloth. Garra refers to a method of dying which involves Preparing the cotton by starching, then folding or tucking the cloth, and securing it with raffia or cotton string. When dyed, the dye does not penetrate the parts where it has been folded or tucked, leaving a geometric pattern. This example has been folded, and dyed with indigo, to create a pattern of vertical zigzag lines.

A piece of garra cloth. Garra refers to a method of dying which involves Preparing the cotton by starching, then folding or tucking the cloth, and securing it with raffia or cotton string. When dyed, the dye does not penetrate the parts where it has been folded or tucked, leaving a geometric pattern. The pattern on this example has, however, been create using batik, or wax. A stamp covered in wax was used to pattern the fabric; when is was dyed with indigo, the waxed pattern was left white.
