A raffia, or grass, skirt. It has alternating panels of dyed black, and natural, raffia. Raffia skirts, such as this one, are often part of the costume of masqueraders, or public performers.

A raffia, or grass, skirt. It has alternating panels of raffia in natural colouring, and dyed red. The Glasgow Museum catalogue notes that is was worn by girls that had been initiated into the Sande society, or sampa.

A carved wooden helmet mask used by the exclusively female Sande (Mende) or Bondo/Bundu (Temne) societies. The mask is traditionally worn by a high-ranking member of the society, the dancing sowei , known as the ndoli jowei among the Mende or a-Nowo among the Temne. Worn with a raffia costume, the masks typically have a polished black finish, with neck rings, elaborate coiffure and dignified facial expression. The mask is thought to represent conceptions of idealised womanhood. This example has a large crescent horn on top of the head, and five vertical grooves above the eyes.
A dancers wand , bound in blue, red, yellow and white glass bead work.
Waist beads, made from numerous strings of red glass beads and coins.
A necklace made out of hollow, brown, rush beads, and small white glass beads. A similar necklace was described by Alldridge as medicine beads .
A forehead band, or circlet, constructed out of blue, white, and orange glass beads.
A beaded bracelet, or anklet, made from tassels of blue, red, and white glass beads.
A necklace, or set of waist beads, made of seeds.
A multi-stranded set of waist beads. The beads are made out of seeds.
A long beaded necklace, or set of waist beads, made from plaited strings of orange glass beads.
A long, narrow, sash, or costume band. It is orange in colour.
A long, narrow, sash, or costume band. It is white in colour.
A long, narrow, sash, or costume band. It is white in colour.
A piece of cloth worn round the waist, known as a lappa. Indigo is likely to have been used as a dye to create the deep blue and white pattern.
A wrist tassel of blue, red, and green dyed raffia.
A wrist tassel of blue, red, and green dyed raffia.
A fine black netted shawl. The Glasgow Museum catalogue notes it was used for dancing .
A metal dancers wand resembling an arrow. The Glasgow Museums catalogue states it was carried by Marjo , the head of the Sande society. It is stamped with the initials RR .

Leg or arm rattles worn by dances and other public performers. They are made from a flat oval piece of iron that is bent over to form a rattle. There is a loop at each end, with two additional loops attached to it that rattle when the wearer moves. These are attached to a leather thong, so that they can be tied to the body.

Leg or arm rattles worn by dances and other public performers. They are made from a flat oval piece of iron that is bent over to form a rattle. There is a loop at each end, with two additional loops attached to it that rattle when the wearer moves. These are attached to a leather thong, so that they can be tied to the body.
A raffia headdress . It is made from raffia in alternating panels of black and brown, attached to a red and white chequered band.
A dancers hat . It is decorated in tufted blue and red wool, coins, and safety pins. The coins are imported, rather than Sierra Leonean, currency.
A wig used by dancers, or public performers. It is made from a series of plaits of hair, sewn together.

CulturalObject.Description: A wig used by dancers, or public performers. It has a crest made from a series of small loops, and two bosses at either side. It is made from a series of plaits of hair, sewn together.
A wig used by dancers, or public performers. It has a crest made from a series of small loops, and two bosses at either side. It is made from a series of plaits of hair, sewn together.
A necklace made out of hollow, yellow, rush beads. A similar necklace was described by Alldridge as medicine beads .

An ankle rattle worn by dances and other public performers. It consists of seven metal disks, bent over to form a rattle. Each one has two rings attached to it and they are collectively threaded onto a piece of string.

This resembles a Sowei Mask, used by the exclusively female Sande (Mende) or Bondo/Bundu (Temne) societies. The mask is traditionally worn by a high-ranking member of the society, the dancing sowei , known as the ndoli jowei among the Mende or a-Nowo among the Temne. Worn with a raffia costume, the masks typically have a polished black finish, with neck rings, elaborate coiffure and dignified facial expression. This example is, however, unusual as it stylistically resembles a gonde mask, particularly in the wide eyes and subtle distortion of form, such as its slight sideways tilt. It has holes in the top ridge for attaching charms, or amulets.

An ankle rattle worn by dances and other public performers. It consists of three metal disks, bent over to form a rattle. Each one has four rings attached to it and they are collectively threaded onto a piece of string.

An ankle rattle worn by dances and other public performers. It consists of eleven metal disks, bent over to form a rattle. Each one has four rings attached to it and they are collectively threaded onto a piece of string.
A circular basket with a square base. The Glasgow Museum catalogue notes that is comes from a collection of Mende and Kissi objects.

A carved wooden helmet mask used by the exclusively female Sande (Mende) or Bondo/Bundu (Temne) societies. The mask is traditionally worn by a high-ranking member of the society, the dancing sowei , known as the ndoli jowei among the Mende or a-Nowo among the Temne. Worn with a raffia costume, the masks typically have a polished black finish, with neck rings, elaborate coiffure and dignified facial expression. The mask is thought to represent conceptions of idealised womanhood. This example is of the rarer casque style , and has a number of scrolls, or charms, attached to the hairstyle. The mask also has three rectangular mirrors around the hair line; mirrors are more commonly associated with Goboi or Bini masqueraders of the male Poro society.

A carved wooden helmet mask used by the exclusively female Sande (Mende) or Bondo/Bundu (Temne) societies. The mask is traditionally worn by a high-ranking member of the society, the dancing sowei , known as the ndoli jowei among the Mende or a-Nowo among the Temne. Worn with a raffia costume, the masks typically have a polished black finish, with neck rings, elaborate coiffure and dignified facial expression. The mask is thought to represent conceptions of idealised womanhood. This example resembles Vai or Gola mask styles and came from the north of Kenema, though may still have been made by a Mende carver. It has a five fan-ridged hairstyle.

A carved wooden helmet mask used by the exclusively female Sande (Mende) or Bondo/Bundu (Temne) societies. The mask is traditionally worn by a high-ranking member of the society, the dancing sowei , known as the ndoli jowei among the Mende or a-Nowo among the Temne. Worn with a raffia costume, the masks typically have a polished black finish, with neck rings, elaborate coiffure and dignified facial expression. This example is thought to have been bought unused and bears a label reading Kpoi tree, 16 December 1954 . The ears have been pierced, and two small metal hoops are strung through for the attachment of further jewellery.

A carved wooden helmet mask used by the exclusively female Sande (Mende) or Bondo/Bundu (Temne) societies. The mask is traditionally worn by a high-ranking member of the society, the dancing sowei , known as the ndoli jowei among the Mende or a-Nowo among the Temne. Worn with a raffia costume, the masks typically have a polished black finish, with neck rings, elaborate coiffure and dignified facial expression. The mask is thought to represent conceptions of idealised womanhood. This example has complex scarification, with crosses running along the forehead. The hairstyle is dome-shaped with tiny horns and a lizard near the top.

A carved wooden helmet mask used by the exclusively female Sande (Mende) or Bondo/Bundu (Temne) societies. The mask is traditionally worn by a high-ranking member of the society, the dancing sowei , known as the ndoli jowei among the Mende or a-Nowo among the Temne. Worn with a raffia costume, the masks typically have a polished black finish, with neck rings, elaborate coiffure and dignified facial expression. The mask is thought to represent conceptions of idealised womanhood. This example has six snakes around the hair, and a pointed-nosed animal at the top.

A carved wooden helmet mask used by the exclusively female Sande (Mende) or Bondo/Bundu (Temne) societies. The mask is traditionally worn by a high-ranking member of the society, the dancing sowei , known as the ndoli jowei among the Mende or a-Nowo among the Temne. Worn with a raffia costume, the masks typically have a polished black finish, with neck rings, elaborate coiffure and dignified facial expression. This example has an elaborated hairstyle adorned with carved cowries, ovals and diamond shapes.

A carved wooden helmet mask used by the exclusively female Sande (Mende) or Bondo/Bundu (Temne) societies. The mask is traditionally worn by a high-ranking member of the society, the dancing sowei , known as the ndoli jowei among the Mende or a-Nowo among the Temne. Worn with a raffia costume, the masks typically have a polished black finish, with neck rings, elaborate coiffure and dignified facial expression. The mask is thought to represent conceptions of idealised womanhood. This example has a particularly finely carved hairstyle consisting of four plaited knots, and six hair crests. The raffia may have sat on the canter in the masks rim, rather than being attached though holes.

A carved wooden helmet mask used by the exclusively female Sande (Mende) or Bondo/Bundu (Temne) societies. The mask is traditionally worn by a high-ranking member of the society, the dancing sowei , known as the ndoli jowei among the Mende or a-Nowo among the Temne. Worn with a raffia costume, the masks typically have a polished black finish, with neck rings, elaborate coiffure and dignified facial expression. The mask is thought to represent conceptions of idealised womanhood. This example is complete with raffia and has a typical four lobed hairstyle. She has scarification along her forehead, on her cheeks and at the corners of the eyes.

A carved wooden helmet mask used by the exclusively female Sande (Mende) or Bondo/Bundu (Temne) societies. The mask is traditionally worn by a high-ranking member of the society, the dancing sowei , known as the ndoli jowei among the Mende or a-Nowo among the Temne. Worn with a raffia costume, the masks typically have a polished black finish, with neck rings, elaborate coiffure and dignified facial expression. The mask is thought to represent conceptions of idealised womanhood. This example is complete with black raffia and has a six-lobed hairstyle. A small bird is attached by a metal plate collar to the top.

CulturalObject.Description: Guy Massie-Taylor collected a series of carvings representing three stages of carving a Sowei mask from a carver in the Kori Chiefdom. The carver was known as Pessima. This is the first stage, showing the outline of the face and four rectangular blocks for the hair.

Guy Massie-Taylor collected a series of carvings representing three stages of carving a Sowei mask from a carver in the Kori Chiefdom. The carver was known as Pessima. This is the second stage; the facial features are now clear. It is yet to be dyed black.

Guy Massie-Taylor collected a series of carvings representing three stages of carving a Sowei mask from a carver in the Kori Chiefdom. The carver was known as Pessima. This is the final stage, complete with raffia and a metal earring through the right ear. The mask has been dyed black, has two human figures and four elephants adorning the hairstyle.

CulturalObject.Description: A carved wooden helmet mask used by the exclusively female Sande (Mende) or Bondo/Bundu (Temne) societies. The mask is traditionally worn by a high-ranking member of the society, the dancing sowei , known as the ndoli jowei among the Mende or a-Nowo among the Temne. Worn with a raffia costume, the masks typically have a polished black finish, with neck rings, elaborate coiffure and dignified facial expression. The mask is thought to represent conceptions of idealised womanhood. This example is thought to have been carved by a carver named Pessima, who made a number of carvings for Guy Massie-Taylor, now at the Glasgow Museum and the British Museum.

This is thought to be a minsereh , or min , figure, though the term has broadly been used to refer to any carved female wooden figures. Min figures are traditionally used as part of the Yasi (Bullom) or Njayei (Mende) society for curing sickness, though they have also been associated with the Sande society. They contain spiritual power which is given to the figure by members of the society rather than the carver. This example wears a necklace of wooden beads, with a central shell pendant.
